name: Kepler-121
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-121 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-121 is a star with 0.595 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.7 times its radius. It is located 1689.78 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-121 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-121 b

Kepler-121 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.18 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-121.

The mass of Kepler-121 b is 7.42 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-121 b is 2.34 that of Earth. At 7.42 Earth masses, Kepler-121 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-121 c

Kepler-121 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.22 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 41.01 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-121.

The mass of Kepler-121 c is 6.92 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-121 c is 2.27 that of Earth. At 6.92 Earth masses, Kepler-121 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-121, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
